title: About
text:
Team member 1: Elise Nackley is a first-year undergraduate student with plans to major in computer science.
Team member 2: Reed Lessing is a sophomore undergraduate student majoring in neuroscience.
Team member 3: Sofia Massare is a first-year undergraduate student with plans to major in public policy.
Team member 4: Connor Rooney is a first-year undergraduate student with plans to major in public policy.
Team member 4: Sirena Lovato is a sophomore undergraduate student majoring in Environmental science.

title: The Wranglers Project
text:
Introduction and data

Identify the source of the data.
The data is exported from the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services.
State when and how it was originally collected (by the original data curator, not necessarily how you found the data).
The data was last collected in 2020 from CMS administrative data for Medicaid beneficiaries available from the Medicaid State Drug Utilization program.
Write a brief description of the observations.
The Medicaid Prescribing Opioid Rates data set provides an overview of the geographic comparisons of opioid prescribing rates by state, county, and zip code. Each observation provides information on geographical areas(country, state, county, and zip code) in the United States and their correlation with current and long-acting opioid rates and medicaid claims from 2016 to 2020.

title: The Wranglers Project
text:
Research question

A well formulated research question.
How do opioid prescription rates differ by geography and time? How are opioid prescription rates expected to change in the future based on geography? Is an individual’s medicaid plan predictive of their geography and opioid insurance claim?
These questions are important because their answers provide in depth information into the roots of the opioid epidemic and possible solutions.
A description of the research topic along with a concise statement of your hypotheses on this topic.
This research topic will explore the correlation between geography, insurance plans, and the opioid epidemic. I would expect low-socioeconomic regions to be prone to high opioid prescriptions as the majority of opioid users are low income individuals. Also, I would expect the more generous insurance plans to have high variability with opioid prescribing rates as moral hazard contributes to accepting prescriptions.
This date set raises ethical concerns relating to the accuracy of the prescription rate reportings. Because of the controversial topic of drugs, many hospitals and physicians may misreport opioid prescription rates. Also, this data set does not consider opioids that were illegally prescribed and bought. Therefore, this data set may not provide our team with all of the information regarding opioid use in the US.
Identify the types of variables in your research question. Categorical? Quantitative?
Data Year - character
geographical level - categorical
geographical code - categorical
geographical description - categorical
plan type - categorical
opioid claims - quantitative
overall claims - quantitative
opioid prescribing rate - quantitative
five year change in opioid prescribing rate - quantitative
one year change in opioid prescribing rate - quantitative
long-acting opioid claims - quantitative
long-acting prescribing rate - quantitative
five year change in long acting opioid prescribing rate - quantitative
one year change in long-acting opioid prescribing rate - quantitative

title: The Wranglers Project
text:
Literature

Find one published credible article on the topic you are interested in researching.
“Geographic Variation in Opioid Prescribing in the US” by Douglas C. McDonald
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3509148/
Provide a one paragraph summary about the article.
This article examines the relationship between geographic locations within the United States and rates of opioid prescribing aiming to discover connections between the opioid epidemic and geographic location. The study found that poorer areas, especially Western Appalachia, have significantly higher rates of opioid prescribing. Other factors that the study considered include the availability of physicians, the general strength of healthcare resources in the area, prescription monitoring laws, characteristics of the area’s populations, and other factors. The study found that the emergence of higher demand for treatment with opioids coupled with the exhaustion of medical resources along with the weak medical consensus on the appropriate use of opioids factor into the over-prescription crisis fueling the opioid epidemic.
In 1-2 sentences, explain how your research question builds on / is different than the article you have cited.
Our research question builds on the article cited by limiting the scope of patients to only Medicare beneficiaries. Because our data set only includes Medicare patients, our team can analyze how opioids are being prescribed to low-income and/or disabled individuals in the United States.

title: The Wranglers Project
text:
Introduction and data

Identify the source of the data.
This data is from the CORGIS Dataset Project and was created in 9/15/2021. The data was compiled from the Washington Post.
State when and how it was originally collected (by the original data curator, not necessarily how you found the data).
The Washington Post regularly collects this data as police shootings happen. The Post collected the data by looking at local news reports, law enforcement websites and social media, and by monitoring independent databases such as Killed by Police and Fatal Encounters. In necessary cases, the Post did additional research.
Write a brief description of the observations.
This dataset collects data on fatal shootings in the United States by a police officer in the line of duty from Jan. 1, 2015 to Sept. 11, 2021. This data includes gender, race, mental illness, location, and date. Each observation represents a fatal shooting event by a police officer.

title: The Wranglers Project
text:
Research question

A well formulated research question. (You may include more than one research question if you want to receive feedback on different ideas for your project. However, one per data set is required.)
How do race, gender, and mental illness affect rates of police shootings over time across the United States?



A description of the research topic along with a concise statement of your hypotheses on this topic.
Our dataset includes 6570 rows meaning that at least 6570 people were killed by police from 2015 to 2021. By discovering how different factors affect the number of shootings, we can begin to understand why these tragedies happen, and what we can do to stop them from happening.
The research topic looks at the correlation between race, gender, and mental illness and police shooting rates. We would expect that male individuals of minority communities with previous mental illnesses would be more likely to be affected.
One ethical concern is the possibility of misinformation in the data and a lack of accurate reporting. Another concern is consent and whether the victims families want their loved ones to have identifying information (like their name and information about their death) in a public database.
Identify the types of variables in your research question. Categorical? Quantitative?
Person.Name - String
Person.Age - Integer Person.Gender - String
Person.Race - String
Incident.Date.Month - Integer Incident.Date.Day - Integer
Incident.Date.Year - Integer
Incident.Date.Full - String
Incident.Location.City - String Incident.Location.State - String
Factors.Armed - String
Factors.Mental-Illness - Boolean
Factors.Threat-Level - String
Factors.Fleeing - String
Shooting.Manner - String
Shooting.Body-Camera - Boolean

title: The Wranglers Project
text:
Literature

Find one published credible article on the topic you are interested in researching.
“What the data say about police shootings” by Lynne Peeples
https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-019-02601-9
Provide a one paragraph summary about the article.
Police officers in the United States fatally shoot about three people per day on average, a number that is close to the yearly totals for other wealthy nations. Data on these deadly encounters has been hard to come by, but five years later, newspapers, enterprising individuals and the federal government have launched ambitious data-collection projects to fill the gaps and improve transparency and accountability over how police officers exercise their right to use deadly force. Social scientists and public-health researchers have produced more than 50 publications to address pressing questions, such as whether the police are disproportionately quick to shoot black civilians and those from other minority groups.
In 1-2 sentences, explain how your research question builds on / is different than the article you have cited.
New databases show that police officers’ use of lethal force is much more common than previously thought, and varies significantly across the country. We plan to track these differences which could help identify opportunities to reduce the number of shootings and deaths for both civilians and police officers.

title: The Wranglers Project
text:
Introduction and data

Identify the source of the data.
We obtained this dataset from the CORGIS Dataset Project.
State when and how it was originally collected (by the original data curator, not necessarily how you found the data).
It was collected by Dr. Austin Cory Bart (currently an Assistant Professor at the University of Delaware) in October, 2016 from the Common Core of Data (CCD), an organization that aims to “provide basic information on public elementary and secondary schools” within the United States.
Write a brief description of the observations.
Each observation represents a state’s annual SAT score report and demographic information.

title: The Wranglers Project
text:
Research question

A well formulated research question. (You may include more than one research question if you want to receive feedback on different ideas for your project. However, one per data set is required.)
How do academic history and demographic factors (like family income and gender) affect standardized test scores of high school students in the United States? How should this inform our interpretation of SAT results?
A description of the research topic along with a concise statement of your hypotheses on this topic.
For this research project, we hope to investigate education inequities in the United States by examining the academic and social factors that influence student performance on the SAT. We hypothesize that social and demographic factors will be a better predictor of SAT score results than academic history.
Identify the types of variables in your research question. Categorical? Quantitative?
Year - Integer
State.Code - String
Total.Math - Integer
Total.Verbal - Integer
Total.Test-takers - Integer
Academic Subjects.English.Average GPA - Float (available for several subject areas)
Academic Subjects.English. Average Years - Float (available for several subject areas)
Family Income.Between 20-40k.Test-takers - Integer (available for several income brackets and test types)
GPA.A minus.Test-takers - Integer (available for several GPA levels and test types)
Gender.Female.Test-takers - Integer (available for male and female students and several test types)
Score Ranges - Integer (available for several test sections)

title: The Wranglers Project
text:
Literature

Find one published credible article on the topic you are interested in researching.
“Is Income Implicit in Measures of Student Ability?” by Jason Sockin
https://budgetmodel.wharton.upenn.edu/issues/2021/9/28/is-income-implicit-in-measures-of-student-ability
Provide a one paragraph summary about the article.
SAT and other standardized tests have become a heavily debated aspect of student education and college admissions, as many US universities have decided to opt for a test-optional admissions process. This brings attention to how possible socioeconomic factors affect student’s academic record, including GPA, high school rank, and standardized test scores. According to data from the National Longitudinal Survey of Youth 1997 analyzed in this article, it was found that income had a weaker correlation with GPA and class rank than the correlation between income and SAT score. Similar correlation strengths were observed for ACT data as well. This article concludes that standardized testing reveals some abilities that are not tested in school and are impacted by environmental factors.
In 1-2 sentences, explain how your research question builds on / is different than the article you have cited.
Building upon this article, our research question will utilize a more current dataset that was compiled in 2016. Additionally, our research question will explore more environmental factors and context, like location and gender.

title: An Analysis of Police Shootings in the United States from 2015-2021
text:
Introduction
Created on September 15, 2021, the police_shootings data set is sourced from the CORGIS Dataset Project and was compiled from findings by The Washington Post. The Washington Post regularly collects this data as police shootings happen by monitoring local news reports, law enforcement websites, social media, and independent databases such as Killed by Police and Fatal Encounters. When necessary, The Post did additional research to investigate each individual case.
This data set describes fatal shootings in the United States by a police officer in the line of duty from January 1, 2015, to September 11, 2021. Each observation represents a fatal shooting event by a police officer. This data includes information on the victim’s gender, race, mental illness, location, and date of the event.
In a Nature article titled “What the data say about police shootings,” Lynne Peeples explains that police officers in the United States fatally shoot about three people per day on average, a number that rivals the yearly totals of other wealthy nations. Data on these deadly encounters had been hard to come by, but five years later, newspapers, enterprising individuals, and the federal government have launched ambitious data-collection projects to fill the gaps and improve transparency and accountability over how police officers exercise their right to use deadly force. Social scientists and public health researchers have produced more than 50 publications to address pressing questions, such as whether the police are disproportionately quick to shoot black civilians and those from other minority groups.
New databases show that police officers' use of lethal force is much more common than previously thought and varies significantly across the country. We plan to track these differences to help identify opportunities to reduce the number of police shootings and deaths for both civilians and police officers.
Research question
How do race, gender, age, and whether a civilian was armed or not affect rates of police shootings across the United States from 2015 to 2021?
Data
Our data set includes 6569 rows, indicating that at least 6569 people were killed by police from 2015 to 2021. By discovering how different factors affect the number of shootings, we can begin to understand why these tragedies happen and what we can do to stop them from happening.
Our research topic examines police shooting history on the basis of race, gender, and age. We hypothesize that male individuals who identify as a POC are most likely to consist of the largest victim population.
Ethical Concerns
One ethical concern is the possibility of misinformation in the data and a lack of accurate reporting. Not every police shooting is reported or handled correctly. Although The Washington Post collected the data from many different sources, there is no way of guaranteeing that the data set is fully comprehensive.
Second, as demonstrated below, all 6,569 victims identified in this data set have been characterized as having a mental illness. As a result, we decide not to make a visualization based on the mental illness variable. We believe this would pose an ethical issue because mental health is a spectrum with varying characteristics and severity of impact. Having a mental illness cannot be reduced to a simple “TRUE” or “FALSE.” Instead, we decided that other variables would be a better focus.

sum(police_shootings$`Factors.Mental-Illness`)

[1] 6569


Finally, a third concern is consent and whether the victims families want their loved ones to have identifying information (like name and information about their death) in a public database. This is a highly sensitive topic and should be treated as such.
The following data was collected randomly and the observations are independent.
We have identified several key variables that will advance our research question: Person.Name - String (Categorical)
Person.Age - Integer (Quantitative)
Person.Gender - String (Categorical)
Person.Race - String (Categorical)
Incident.Date.Month - Integer (Categorical)
Incident.Date.Day - Integer (Quantitative)
Incident.Date.Year - Integer (Quantitative)
Incident.Date.Full - String (Categorical)
Incident.Location.City - String (Categorical)
Incident.Location.State - String (Categorical)
Factors.Armed - String (Categorical)
Factors.Mental-Illness - Boolean (Categorical)
Factors.Threat-Level - String (Categorical)
Factors.Fleeing - String (Categorical)
Shooting.Manner - String (Categorical)
Shooting.Body-Camera - Boolean (Categorical)
Methodology
The average age for a police shooting victim is 35; whereas, the median age is 34. We can conclude that the data is not central to 34-35 years of age as the standard deviation of the the victim’s age is ~15 years.

police_shootings |>
  summarize(mean_age = mean(Person.Age),
            median_age = median(Person.Age),
            stdv_age = sd(Person.Age))

# A tibble: 1 × 3

As seen by the map, the majority of our data was collected in California. This could be a limitation to our data as it demonstartes biases.
In yearly-analysis, we chose to do a line graph to represent the progression of shooting per day over time as it effectively reveals trends and changes in shooting per day across the years.

yearly_shootings <- police_shootings |>
  group_by(Incident.Date.Year) |>
  count(Incident.Date.Year) 

days_in_year <- c(365, 366, 365, 365, 365, 366, 253)

yearly_shootings |>
  ggplot(aes(x = Incident.Date.Year, y = n/days_in_year)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_line() +
  labs(
    title = "Fig. 1: Shootings per Day",
    x = "Year", 
    y = "Number of Shootings")




As seen by the graph below, ~10% of male victims and 13% of female victims were unarmed.

police_shootings_fit <- police_shootings |>
 filter(`Factors.Threat-Level` != "unknown") |>
 mutate(Factors.Armed.Test = if_else(Factors.Armed == "unarmed" | 
                                        Factors.Armed == "toy weapon", "unarmed"
                                      , "armed with weapon"),
         race = if_else(Person.Race != "White", "POC", "White"), 
        `Factors.Threat-Level`= if_else(`Factors.Threat-Level` == "attack", 
                                        "attack", "not specified as attack"),
        `Factors.Threat-Level`= as.factor(`Factors.Threat-Level`)) 

best_logreg_model <- logistic_reg() |> 
  set_engine("glm") |>
  fit(`Factors.Threat-Level` ~ race + Person.Gender + Factors.Armed.Test + Person.Age, 
      data = police_shootings_fit, family = "binomial") 

best_logreg_model |> 
  glance() |>
  pull(AIC)

[1] 8485.761

best_logreg_model |>
  tidy()

# A tibble: 6 × 5
  term                      estimate std.error statistic  p.value
  <chr>                        <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>    <dbl>
1 (Intercept)               -0.229     0.138      -1.66  9.61e- 2
2 raceWhite                 -0.114     0.0539     -2.12  3.38e- 2
3 Person.GenderMale         -0.245     0.123      -1.98  4.74e- 2
4 Person.GenderUnknown       1.04      1.23        0.843 3.99e- 1
5 Factors.Armed.Testunarmed  0.653     0.0835      7.81  5.66e-15
6 Person.Age                -0.00419   0.00180    -2.33  1.98e- 2


\(\log{\frac{p}{1-p}}\) = -0.229153274 -0.114483595 * (\(race\_white\)) - 0.244889178 * (\(Person.Gender\_Male\)) + 1.038480834 * (\(Person.Gender\_Unknown\)) + 0.652516293 * (\(Factors.Armed.Test\_unarmed\)) - 0.004189227 * (\(Person.Age\))
Where \(p\) is the probability of a person being a perceived threat by the police, stating the incident as an “attack.”
After fitting the logistic model and computing backwards elimination, we found the best model for our response variable (Factors.Threat.Level) to be an additive model between our four explanatory variables: gender, race, armed status, and age. During backwards elimination, we fit several additive and interactive models between the four variables and determined the lowest AIC value. Therefore, whether or not a victim was seen as a threat was explained with an additive interaction between gender, race, armed status, and age.
We will now investigate if the proportion of unarmed people who were shot by police is equal for victims of color in comparison to white victims. We hypothesize that the proportion of unarmed people of color shot is significantly greater than the proportion of unarmed white people. In order to investigate this hypothesis, we will perform a hypothesis test using a significance level of \(\alpha = 0.05\). For the hypothesis testing purposes, we will assume independence within our data set’s observations.
(Note: in the context of this question, we will consider someone as a “POC” if they do not identify as “White”)
\(\pi_{POC}\) = the proportion of unarmed people out of those shot who identify as a POC.
\(\pi_{White}\) = the proportion of unarmed people out of those shot who identify as a White
\(H_o\): \(\pi_{POC}\) = \(\pi_{White}\)
The proportion of unarmed people out of those shot who identify as a POC is equal to the proportion of unarmed people out of those shot who identify as white.
\(H_A\): \(\pi_{POC}\) > \(\pi_{White}\)
The proportion of unarmed people out of those shot who identify as a POC is greater than the proportion of unarmed people out of those shot who identify as white.

hypo_data <- police_shootings |>
  filter(Factors.Armed != "unknown", Person.Race != "Unknown") |>
  mutate(Factors.Armed.Test = if_else(Factors.Armed == "unarmed" | 
                                        Factors.Armed == "toy weapon", "unarmed"
                                      , "armed with weapon"),
         race = if_else(Person.Race != "White", "POC", "White")) 
set.seed(69)
null_dist <- hypo_data |>
  specify(response = Factors.Armed.Test, 
          explanatory = race , success = "unarmed") |>
  hypothesize(null = "independence") |>
  generate(reps = 1000, type = "permute") |>
  calculate(stat = "diff in props" , order = c("POC", "White"))


hypo_data |>
  group_by(race, Factors.Armed.Test) |>
  summarize(props = n())

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'race'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.


# A tibble: 4 × 3
# Groups:   race [2]
  race  Factors.Armed.Test props
  <chr> <chr>              <int>
1 POC   armed with weapon   2456
2 POC   unarmed              318
3 White armed with weapon   2568
4 White unarmed              299

p_hat_POC <- 318/(318+2456)
p_hat_white <- 299/(299+2568)
obs_diff_phat <- p_hat_POC - p_hat_white

visualize(null_dist) +
 shade_p_value(obs_stat = obs_diff_phat, direction = "greater") +
  labs(title = "Fig. 7 Simulated Null Distribution")



null_dist |>
  get_p_value(obs_stat = obs_diff_phat, direction = "greater")

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  p_value
    <dbl>
1   0.107


Results
Based on our summary statistics for the entire data set, we observed that the mean and median age of shooting victims is 35.4 and 34.0 years, respectively. Moreover, the standard deviation of this age range is 14.9 years, demonstrating the wide spread of data points included. We noticed a slight decrease in shooting per day in 2021 though the total range of average shootings per day was small and somewhat insignificant (from roughly 2.45 shootings to 2.8 shootings). When looking at the arms status of victims by gender, female victims were more likely to be armed than male victims. One reason for this is that male victims could have been seen as more aggressive and therefore more likely to become a victim no matter if they were armed. The age distribution of victims does not vary much between races. When we look at the different races in the count of total victims, we can see white victims and African American victims were most common. Close to 2962 of the victims were white; whereas, 1552 victims were black. If race had no impact on probability of being a victim, the proportions of victims by race would be similar as the US population by race. White Americans represent 0.578 of the population. African Americans make up 0.121 of the population.

police_shootings |>
  count(Person.Race)

# A tibble: 7 × 2
  Person.Race          n
  <chr>            <int>
1 African American  1552
2 Asian              106
3 Hispanic          1081
4 Native American     91
5 Other               47
6 Unknown            730
7 White             2962

white_american_prop <- 2962/6569
white_american_prop

[1] 0.4509058

african_american_prop <- 1552/6569  
african_american_prop

[1] 0.2362612


White Americans represent 0.578 of the US population while they only represent 0.45 of the victims. African Americans make up 0.121 of the population while they present 0.236 of the victims.Therefore we can see that African American were targeted at a higher rate than white Americans.
The race with the most unarmed victims was black and the race with the least unarmed victims was Native American. Visualization can provide ample information on implicit bias and how race impacts the police’s approaches to interactions with different races. We also found the median age is roughly 34 years old for males and 35 years old for females. Male victims differ by their outliers, as many male victims are over the age of 75. The unknown victims appear to be significantly younger as seen by the median of ~21 years old. We performed a hypothesis test proportion of unarmed people out of those shot who identify as a POC is equal to the proportion of unarmed people out of those shot who identify as white, and got a p-value of 0.107. Utilizing a significance level of 0.05, we fail to reject the null hypothesis that the proportion of unarmed people out of those shot who identify as a POC is equal to the proportion of unarmed people out of those shot who identify as white, as 0.107 is greater than 0.05. Therefore, we have weak evidence to support the alternative hypothesis that the proportion of unarmed people out of those shot who identify as a POC is greater than the proportion of unarmed people out of those shot who identify as white.
Discussion and Limitations
As seen in the map plotting the state location of incidents, the majority of the shootings were centered around California. However, this creates concern for our project as the data appears to be very biased and unethical.
